awd_titl_txt: Rationing the Commons: A Research Program on the Efficiency of Institutions for Groundwater Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Society has clear ideals of how to manage common resources (commons); however, commons fail---carbon dioxide fills the air, fisheries collapse, and wells dry up. Two methods that are used to manage the commons formal method which imposes taxes, and informal community management that limits access---have problems. Taxes on the use of commons are difficult to collect and may harm some low-income users while local controls cannot meet the large amount of resources required to manage the commons. This proposed research will use field experiments and economic theory to develop a "second best" commons management model that combines both methods of managing the commons mentioned above. The model is then tested for efficiency in managing ground water commons; the research also calculates the efficiency gains from using this new management approach. The results of this research project will provide important tools to manage the commons, such as air quality, water, and parks among others. This will not only improve efficiency in resource management in the US; it will also establish the US as the global leader in management of the commons. 

The research program has two parts. The first part studies the efficiency of current institutions for managing groundwater commons. The main institution for groundwater management in many countries is electricity rationing. Farmers use electric pumps to extract water with heavily subsidized electricity, so they over use this "free water". The state knows little about the value of the commons for users but can enforce limits on electricity use. This research will estimate enough statistics for efficiency loss from this commons management regime and then estimate a structural model of agricultural production to study the efficiency of counterfactual management policies, such as pricing power and water. The second part will test a new commons policy through a field experiment. The policy, Direct Benefit Transfers for Electricity, raises the marginal price of electricity in exchange for lump-sum transfers that compensate for the loss of marginal electricity subsidies. The outcomes of power and water savings and agricultural adaptation in the experiment will mirror the structural estimates of the response of farmers to higher power prices. In this way, the research program will both estimate a model to study a new commons policy and validate the gains from that policy in a field experiment. The results of this research will improve the efficiency of resource allocation and therefore increase economic efficiency in the US and throughout the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many common resources around the world are being spoiled or depleted. Examples include groundwater, surface water, fishing stocks and clean air. Climate change is the largest commons problem of all, caused by emissions of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels. Economists recommend solving these problems with markets—a price for the use of the common resource, or a limit on the amount of resource use that can then be traded across users. But many commons are not managed with markets. This project has studied the consequences of managing a large common resource with strict, uniform rules instead of with markets. It has resulted in new academic research but also broader impacts through new policies and policy recommendations and student training.

The first output from the project is a better understanding of the costs of managing a common resource without markets. We studied the use of groundwater by farmers in India. India, China and the United States are the largest users of groundwater in the world; the productivity of agriculture in these countries depends to a large extent on farmers being able to pump water out of the ground, so they do not have to rely on uncertain rainfall to grow their crops. India manages such pumping by rationing—limiting the amount of time farmers can pump each day. We ran a large original survey of farmers to collect data on agriculture and analyzed the effect of the rationing system on agricultural productivity. The published results show that rationing does provide an effective limit on the total amount of groundwater use by farmers. This limit, however, comes at a high cost. The rationing system cuts farmers’ income by 12%, a huge effect in an already poor environment. The reason is that rationing is an inefficient way to allocate water. All farmers get about the same amount, regardless of whether they are more or less productive in using that water to grow agricultural produce. This result shows the real costs of managing a common resource without using markets.

The likely reason that this regime persists, despite being so costly on average, is that some farmers would be disadvantaged by a reform that charged them more for high levels of water use. The second output from the project is two pilots that have provided proof-of-concept to solve this problem of groundwater mismanagement. The pilots, in the Indian states of Rajasthan and Punjab, asked farmers to voluntarily adopt a higher price for pumping in exchange for a fixed amount of money (regardless of how much they pump). This higher price gives farmers an incentive to conserve resources, while the fixed payment offsets the cost to farmers from facing a high price. We find that such incentives work. For example, in Rajasthan, farmers with incentives cut their electricity usage for pumping by one-quarter. While water is scarce and precious to farmers in this semi-arid state, like in the American west, it is not the case that there is no scope for incentives to help conserve water.  The carrying out of the project aided several graduate students and research assistants in their training in economics, and also inspired a research assistant to attend graduate school in hydrology.

The broader impacts of the project are through the lessons it generates for policy. Within India the project has provided an example of how groundwater can be managed better without harming farmers who are relatively less well off.  This example has already proven to be valuable as other states follow the pilot states in seeking to reform their systems of agricultural tariff subsidies. The central government has mandated a tariff subsidy reform that shares some features with the subsidy reform that we piloted. For the rest of the world, the findings provide a methodology to measure the costs of introducing stringent environmental limits without using markets for enforcement. To mitigate global climate change will require innumerable investments in energy, transportation, construction, agriculture and other sectors all around the world. With existing technology it would be possible to abate carbon dioxide emissions through uniform mandates and limits on energy use—the equivalent of India’s rations, under which farmers to use at most a certain number of hours of electricity per day. But such an approach would have a very large cost, far higher than would be necessary to achieve the same level of carbon abatement. The broad lesson from the study is therefore not to credit a rule, limit or mandate because it can achieve the physical goal of a certain policy, such as a limit on water use or on carbon emissions, but always to ask whether this same physical goal could be achieved at a lower social cost.
